title: 105_hr3170
content: Section 1 introduces a new section 1260 in the Internal Revenue Code, which deals with gains from constructive ownership transactions. The new section 1260 in the Internal Revenue Code addresses gain from constructive ownership transactions. If a taxpayer has gain from such a transaction that would be long-term capital gain, it will be treated as short-term capital gain if it exceeds the net underlying long-term capital gain. The capital gain rate applicable will be based on the rates that would have applied to the net underlying long-term capital gain. An interest charge may apply if gain is treated as short-term. The new section 1260 in the Internal Revenue Code addresses gain from constructive ownership transactions. If a taxpayer has gain from such a transaction that would be long-term capital gain, it will be treated as short-term capital gain if it exceeds the net underlying long-term capital gain. An interest charge may apply if gain is treated as short-term, increasing the taxpayer's tax for the taxable year. The new section 1260 in the Internal Revenue Code addresses gain from constructive ownership transactions. Any amount payable under this paragraph affects the deduction for interest paid or accrued. An increase in tax from such transactions does not count towards certain tax credits. The term 'financial position' refers to positions related to stock, debt instruments, partnership interests, or investment trust interests. The term 'financial position' encompasses positions related to stock, debt instruments, partnership interests, or investment trust interests, including futures contracts, short sales, and options. Taxpayers are considered to have entered into constructive ownership transactions if they hold long positions under notional principal contracts or enter into forward or futures contracts for the same or similar property. The section discusses constructive ownership transactions involving the acquisition of substantially identical property through various means such as forward contracts, options, or similar transactions. The exception applies if all positions in the transaction are marked to market. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of long position, forward contract, and related person in the context of constructive ownership transactions involving substantially identical property. The term 'related person' is defined in section 1259(c)(4), and 'net underlying long-term capital gain' in constructive ownership transactions refers to the aggregate net capital gain that would have occurred if the financial position was acquired and sold on specific dates, considering only gains and losses from deemed ownership. The net underlying long-term capital gain in constructive ownership transactions is treated as zero unless proven otherwise. If a taxpayer elects the Mark to Market option, they must recognize gain or loss on open transactions as if the financial position was sold at fair market value on the last business day of the taxable year. In constructive ownership transactions, any gain or loss must be accounted for in the taxable year. The character of the gain or loss is treated as ordinary income or loss. If a gain or loss is recognized before the close of the taxable year, special rules apply. In constructive ownership transactions, any gain or loss must be accounted for in the taxable year as ordinary income or loss. An election under this provision can be made without the Secretary's consent and applies to the year made and subsequent years unless revoked. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this section. The amendments made by this section apply to gain recognized after the enactment of this Act.
